body.p: “I see the small aster (?) in the woods with ink-black spots at the base of the leaves. (It looks like a dumosus “,” but has no flowers.) White oak acorns have many of them fallen. They are small and very neat light-green acorns “,” with small cups “,” commonly arranged two by two close together “,” often with a leaf growing between them; but frequently three “,” forming a little star with three rays “,” looking very artificial. Some black scrub oak acorns have fallen “,” and a few black oak acorns also have fallen.”
PE 9, pg. 35 / 3 Sept, 1854 – 12 May, 1855 / NNPM MA 1302:24 / T. # XVIII / PDF # XIII
